newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft says U.S. seeks WebTV details.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft says U.S. seeks WebTV details.

text.p: The U.S. Justice Department's antitrust division has made a second request for information regarding Microsoft Corp.'s planned acquisition of WebTV Networks Inc., a company spokesman said Monday.

Company spokesman Mark Murray said the request was routine, and he said executives were confident that regulators would approve Microsoft's proposal to acquire the Internet service provider for $425 million in cash and stock.
The Justice Department initiated its investigation and made an initial request for information under the Hart-Scott-Rodino antitrust law after Microsoft announced the proposed acquisition April 6.
"We intend to provide all the necessary information, and we're completely confident that once they've reviewed all the information they'll approve this merger in short order," Murray said.

WebTV Networks provides Internet access using televisions rather than computers through technology including a special set-top box. Other high-tech companies are pursuing similar technologies to broaden Internet access.
But Murray noted that Microsoft currently does not offer any such service.
"There's no overlap between the business of Microsoft and WebTV," he said. "If there's no overlap, there's no antitrust case."
